trans-unit.source: Create and preconfigure a Windows Virtual Machine with Resource Manager and Azure PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Create and preconfigure a Windows Virtual Machine with Resource Manager and Azure PowerShell

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use Azure PowerShell to create and preconfigure Windows and Resource Manager-based virtual machines in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use Azure PowerShell to create and preconfigure Windows and Resource Manager-based virtual machines in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Create and preconfigure a Windows Virtual Machine with Resource Manager and Azure PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Create and preconfigure a Windows Virtual Machine with Resource Manager and Azure PowerShell

trans-unit.source: These steps show you how to construct a set of commands in the Resource Manager mode of Azure PowerShell that create and pre-configure a Windows-based Azure virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: These steps show you how to construct a set of commands in the Resource Manager mode of Azure PowerShell that create and pre-configure a Windows-based Azure virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: You can use this building block process to quickly create a command set for a new Windows-based virtual machine and expand an existing deployment.
trans-unit.target: You can use this building block process to quickly create a command set for a new Windows-based virtual machine and expand an existing deployment.

trans-unit.source: You can also use it to create multiple command sets that quickly build out a custom dev/test or IT pro environment.
trans-unit.target: You can also use it to create multiple command sets that quickly build out a custom dev/test or IT pro environment.

trans-unit.source: These steps follow a fill-in-the-blanks approach for creating Azure PowerShell command sets.
trans-unit.target: These steps follow a fill-in-the-blanks approach for creating Azure PowerShell command sets.

trans-unit.source: This approach can be useful if you are new to PowerShell or you just want to know what values to specify for successful configuration.
trans-unit.target: This approach can be useful if you are new to PowerShell or you just want to know what values to specify for successful configuration.

trans-unit.source: If you are an advanced PowerShell user, you can take the commands and substitute your own values for the variables (the lines beginning with "$")
trans-unit.target: If you are an advanced PowerShell user, you can take the commands and substitute your own values for the variables (the lines beginning with "$")

trans-unit.source: Use Azure PowerShell to create and preconfigure Windows-based Virtual Machines
trans-unit.target: Use Azure PowerShell to create and preconfigure Windows-based Virtual Machines

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Install Azure PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Install Azure PowerShell

trans-unit.source: You must also have Azure PowerShell version 0.9.0 or later.
trans-unit.target: You must also have Azure PowerShell version 0.9.0 or later.

trans-unit.source: If you have not installed and configured Azure PowerShell, click [here](../powershell-install-configure.md) for instructions.
trans-unit.target: If you have not installed and configured Azure PowerShell, click [here](../powershell-install-configure.md) for instructions.

trans-unit.source: You can check the version of Azure PowerShell that you have installed with this command at the Azure PowerShell prompt.
trans-unit.target: You can check the version of Azure PowerShell that you have installed with this command at the Azure PowerShell prompt.

trans-unit.source: Here is an example.
trans-unit.target: Here is an example.

trans-unit.source: If you do not have Version 0.9.0 or later, you must remove Azure PowerShell using the Programs and Features Control Panel and then install the latest version.
trans-unit.target: If you do not have Version 0.9.0 or later, you must remove Azure PowerShell using the Programs and Features Control Panel and then install the latest version.

trans-unit.source: See [How to Install and Configure Azure PowerShell](../powershell-install-configure.md) for more information.
trans-unit.target: See [How to Install and Configure Azure PowerShell](../powershell-install-configure.md) for more information.

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Set your subscription
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Set your subscription

trans-unit.source: First, run an Azure PowerShell prompt.
trans-unit.target: First, run an Azure PowerShell prompt.

trans-unit.source: Next, set your Azure subscription by running these commands at the Azure PowerShell prompt.
trans-unit.target: Next, set your Azure subscription by running these commands at the Azure PowerShell prompt.

trans-unit.source: Replace everything within the quotes, including the < and > characters, with the correct names.
trans-unit.target: Replace everything within the quotes, including the < and > characters, with the correct names.

trans-unit.source: You can get the correct subscription name from the display of this command.
trans-unit.target: You can get the correct subscription name from the display of this command.

trans-unit.source: Next, switch Azure PowerShell into Resource Manager mode.
trans-unit.target: Next, switch Azure PowerShell into Resource Manager mode.

trans-unit.source: Step 3: Create the required resources
trans-unit.target: Step 3: Create the required resources

trans-unit.source: Resource Manager-based virtual machines require a resource group.
trans-unit.target: Resource Manager-based virtual machines require a resource group.

trans-unit.source: If needed, create a new resource group for your new virtual machine with these commands.
trans-unit.target: If needed, create a new resource group for your new virtual machine with these commands.

trans-unit.source: Replace everything within the quotes, including the < and > characters, with the correct names.
trans-unit.target: Replace everything within the quotes, including the < and > characters, with the correct names.

trans-unit.source: To determine a unique resource group name, use this command to list your existing resource groups.
trans-unit.target: To determine a unique resource group name, use this command to list your existing resource groups.

trans-unit.source: To list the Azure locations where you can create Resource Manager-based virtual machines, use these commands.
trans-unit.target: To list the Azure locations where you can create Resource Manager-based virtual machines, use these commands.

trans-unit.source: Resource Manager-based virtual machines require a Resource Manager-based storage account.
trans-unit.target: Resource Manager-based virtual machines require a Resource Manager-based storage account.

trans-unit.source: If needed, create a new storage account for your new virtual machine with these commands.
trans-unit.target: If needed, create a new storage account for your new virtual machine with these commands.

trans-unit.source: You must pick a globally unique name for your storage account that contains only lowercase letters and numbers.
trans-unit.target: You must pick a globally unique name for your storage account that contains only lowercase letters and numbers.

trans-unit.source: You can use this command to list the existing storage accounts.
trans-unit.target: You can use this command to list the existing storage accounts.

trans-unit.source: To test whether a chosen storage account name is globally unique, you need to run the **Test-AzureName** command in the Azure Service Management mode of PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: To test whether a chosen storage account name is globally unique, you need to run the **Test-AzureName** command in the Azure Service Management mode of PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Use these commands.
trans-unit.target: Use these commands.

trans-unit.source: If the Test-AzureName command displays "False", your proposed name is unique.
trans-unit.target: If the Test-AzureName command displays "False", your proposed name is unique.

trans-unit.source: When you have determined a unique name, switch Azure PowerShell back to Resource Manager mode with this command.
trans-unit.target: When you have determined a unique name, switch Azure PowerShell back to Resource Manager mode with this command.

trans-unit.source: Resource Manager-based virtual machines can use a public domain name label, which can contain only letters, numbers, and hyphens.
trans-unit.target: Resource Manager-based virtual machines can use a public domain name label, which can contain only letters, numbers, and hyphens.

trans-unit.source: The first and last character in the field must be a letter or number.
trans-unit.target: The first and last character in the field must be a letter or number.

trans-unit.source: To test whether a chosen domain name label is globally unique, use these commands.
trans-unit.target: To test whether a chosen domain name label is globally unique, use these commands.

trans-unit.source: If DNSNameAvailability is "True", your proposed name is globally unique.
trans-unit.target: If DNSNameAvailability is "True", your proposed name is globally unique.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] The Test-AzureDnsAvailability cmdlet was named Get-AzureCheckDnsAvailability in versions of Azure PowerShell earlier than version 0.9.5.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] The Test-AzureDnsAvailability cmdlet was named Get-AzureCheckDnsAvailability in versions of Azure PowerShell earlier than version 0.9.5.

trans-unit.source: If you're using version 0.9.4 or earlier, replace Test-AzureDnsAvailability with Get-AzureCheckDnsAvailability in the command shown above.
trans-unit.target: If you're using version 0.9.4 or earlier, replace Test-AzureDnsAvailability with Get-AzureCheckDnsAvailability in the command shown above.

trans-unit.source: Resource Manager-based virtual machines can be placed in a Resource Manager-based availability set.
trans-unit.target: Resource Manager-based virtual machines can be placed in a Resource Manager-based availability set.

trans-unit.source: If needed, create a new availability set for the new virtual machine with these commands.
trans-unit.target: If needed, create a new availability set for the new virtual machine with these commands.

trans-unit.source: Use this command to list the existing availability sets.
trans-unit.target: Use this command to list the existing availability sets.

trans-unit.source: Resource Manager-based virtual machines can be configured with inbound NAT rules to allow incoming traffic from the Internet and be placed in a load balanced set.
trans-unit.target: Resource Manager-based virtual machines can be configured with inbound NAT rules to allow incoming traffic from the Internet and be placed in a load balanced set.

trans-unit.source: In both cases, you must specify a load balancer instance and other settings.
trans-unit.target: In both cases, you must specify a load balancer instance and other settings.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Create a load balancer using Azure Resource Manager](../load-balancer/load-balancer-arm-powershell.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Create a load balancer using Azure Resource Manager](../load-balancer/load-balancer-arm-powershell.md).

trans-unit.source: Resource Manager-based virtual machines require a Resource Manager-based virtual network.
trans-unit.target: Resource Manager-based virtual machines require a Resource Manager-based virtual network.

trans-unit.source: If needed, create a new Resource Manager-based virtual network with at least one subnet for the new virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: If needed, create a new Resource Manager-based virtual network with at least one subnet for the new virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Here is an example for a new virtual network with two subnets named frontendSubnet and backendSubnet.
trans-unit.target: Here is an example for a new virtual network with two subnets named frontendSubnet and backendSubnet.

trans-unit.source: Use these commands to list the existing virtual networks.
trans-unit.target: Use these commands to list the existing virtual networks.

trans-unit.source: Step 4: Build your command set
trans-unit.target: Step 4: Build your command set

trans-unit.source: Open a fresh instance of the text editor of your choice or the PowerShell Integrated Scripting Environment (ISE) and copy the following lines to start your command set.
trans-unit.target: Open a fresh instance of the text editor of your choice or the PowerShell Integrated Scripting Environment (ISE) and copy the following lines to start your command set.

trans-unit.source: Specify the name of the resource group, Azure location, and storage account for this new virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Specify the name of the resource group, Azure location, and storage account for this new virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Replace everything within the quotes, including the < and > characters, with the correct names.
trans-unit.target: Replace everything within the quotes, including the < and > characters, with the correct names.

trans-unit.source: You must specify the name of a Resource Manager-based virtual network and the index number of a subnet in the virtual network.
trans-unit.target: You must specify the name of a Resource Manager-based virtual network and the index number of a subnet in the virtual network.

trans-unit.source: Use these commands to list the subnets for a virtual network.
trans-unit.target: Use these commands to list the subnets for a virtual network.

trans-unit.source: The subnet index is the number of the subnet in the display of this command, numbering them consecutively from left to right and starting at 0.
trans-unit.target: The subnet index is the number of the subnet in the display of this command, numbering them consecutively from left to right and starting at 0.

trans-unit.source: For this example:
trans-unit.target: For this example:

trans-unit.source: The subnet index for the frontendSubnet is 0 and the subnet index for the backendSubnet is 1.
trans-unit.target: The subnet index for the frontendSubnet is 0 and the subnet index for the backendSubnet is 1.

trans-unit.source: Copy these lines to your command set and specify an existing virtual network name and the subnet index for the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Copy these lines to your command set and specify an existing virtual network name and the subnet index for the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Next, you create a network interface card (NIC).
trans-unit.target: Next, you create a network interface card (NIC).

trans-unit.source: Copy one of the following options to your command set and fill in the needed information.
trans-unit.target: Copy one of the following options to your command set and fill in the needed information.

trans-unit.source: Option 1: Specify a NIC name and assign a public IP address
trans-unit.target: Option 1: Specify a NIC name and assign a public IP address

trans-unit.source: Copy the following lines to your command set and specify the name for the NIC.
trans-unit.target: Copy the following lines to your command set and specify the name for the NIC.

trans-unit.source: Option 2: Specify a NIC name and a DNS domain name label
trans-unit.target: Option 2: Specify a NIC name and a DNS domain name label

trans-unit.source: Copy the following lines to your command set and specify the name for the NIC and the globally unique domain name label.
trans-unit.target: Copy the following lines to your command set and specify the name for the NIC and the globally unique domain name label.

trans-unit.source: When you create virtual machines in the Service Management mode of Azure PowerShell, Azure completes these steps automatically.
trans-unit.target: When you create virtual machines in the Service Management mode of Azure PowerShell, Azure completes these steps automatically.

trans-unit.source: Option 3: Specify a NIC name and assign a static, private IP address
trans-unit.target: Option 3: Specify a NIC name and assign a static, private IP address

trans-unit.source: Copy the following lines to your command set and specify the name for the NIC.
trans-unit.target: Copy the following lines to your command set and specify the name for the NIC.

trans-unit.source: Option 4: Specify a NIC name and a load balancer instance for an inbound NAT rule.
trans-unit.target: Option 4: Specify a NIC name and a load balancer instance for an inbound NAT rule.

trans-unit.source: To create a NIC and add it to a load balancer instance for an inbound NAT rule, you need:
trans-unit.target: To create a NIC and add it to a load balancer instance for an inbound NAT rule, you need:

trans-unit.source: The name of a previously-created load balancer instance that has an inbound NAT rule for traffic being forwarded to the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: The name of a previously-created load balancer instance that has an inbound NAT rule for traffic being forwarded to the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: The index number of the back end address pool of the load balancer instance to assign to the NIC.
trans-unit.target: The index number of the back end address pool of the load balancer instance to assign to the NIC.

trans-unit.source: The index number of the inbound NAT rule to assign to the NIC.
trans-unit.target: The index number of the inbound NAT rule to assign to the NIC.

trans-unit.source: For information on how to create a load balancer instance with inbound NAT rules, see [Create a load balancer using Azure Resource Manager](../load-balancer/load-balancer-arm-powershell.md).
trans-unit.target: For information on how to create a load balancer instance with inbound NAT rules, see [Create a load balancer using Azure Resource Manager](../load-balancer/load-balancer-arm-powershell.md).

trans-unit.source: Copy these lines to your command set and specify the needed names and index numbers.
trans-unit.target: Copy these lines to your command set and specify the needed names and index numbers.

trans-unit.source: The $nicName string must be unique for the resource group.
trans-unit.target: The $nicName string must be unique for the resource group.

trans-unit.source: A best practice is to incorporate the virtual machine name in the string, such as "LOB07-NIC".
trans-unit.target: A best practice is to incorporate the virtual machine name in the string, such as "LOB07-NIC".

trans-unit.source: Option 5: Specify a NIC name and a load balancer instance for a load-balanced set.
trans-unit.target: Option 5: Specify a NIC name and a load balancer instance for a load-balanced set.

trans-unit.source: To create a NIC and add it to a load balancer instance for a load-balanced set, you need:
trans-unit.target: To create a NIC and add it to a load balancer instance for a load-balanced set, you need:

trans-unit.source: The name of a previously-created load balancer instance that has a rule for the load-balanced traffic.
trans-unit.target: The name of a previously-created load balancer instance that has a rule for the load-balanced traffic.

trans-unit.source: The index number of the back end address pool of the load balancer instance to assign to the NIC.
trans-unit.target: The index number of the back end address pool of the load balancer instance to assign to the NIC.

trans-unit.source: For information on how to create a load balancer instance with rules for load-balanced traffic, see [Create a load balancer using Azure Resource Manager](../load-balancer/load-balancer-arm-powershell.md).
trans-unit.target: For information on how to create a load balancer instance with rules for load-balanced traffic, see [Create a load balancer using Azure Resource Manager](../load-balancer/load-balancer-arm-powershell.md).

trans-unit.source: Copy these lines to your command set and specify the needed names and index numbers.
trans-unit.target: Copy these lines to your command set and specify the needed names and index numbers.

trans-unit.source: Next, create a local VM object and optionally add it to an availability set.
trans-unit.target: Next, create a local VM object and optionally add it to an availability set.

trans-unit.source: Copy one of the two following options to your command set and fill in the name, size, and availability set name.
trans-unit.target: Copy one of the two following options to your command set and fill in the name, size, and availability set name.

trans-unit.source: Option 1: Specify a virtual machine name and size.
trans-unit.target: Option 1: Specify a virtual machine name and size.

trans-unit.source: To determine the possible values of the VM size string for option 1, use these commands.
trans-unit.target: To determine the possible values of the VM size string for option 1, use these commands.

trans-unit.source: Option 2: Specify a virtual machine name and size and add it to an availability set.
trans-unit.target: Option 2: Specify a virtual machine name and size and add it to an availability set.

trans-unit.source: To determine the possible values of the VM size string for option 2, use these commands.
trans-unit.target: To determine the possible values of the VM size string for option 2, use these commands.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Currently with Resource Manager, you can only add a virtual machine to an availability set during its creation.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Currently with Resource Manager, you can only add a virtual machine to an availability set during its creation.

trans-unit.source: To add an additional data disk to the VM, copy these lines to your command set and specify the disk settings.
trans-unit.target: To add an additional data disk to the VM, copy these lines to your command set and specify the disk settings.

trans-unit.source: Next, you need to determine the publisher, offer, and SKU of the image for your virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Next, you need to determine the publisher, offer, and SKU of the image for your virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Here is a table of commonly-used, Windows-based images.
trans-unit.target: Here is a table of commonly-used, Windows-based images.

trans-unit.source: Publisher name
trans-unit.target: Publisher name

trans-unit.source: Offer name
trans-unit.target: Offer name

trans-unit.source: SKU name
trans-unit.target: SKU name

trans-unit.source: MicrosoftWindowsServer
trans-unit.target: MicrosoftWindowsServer

trans-unit.source: WindowsServer
trans-unit.target: WindowsServer

trans-unit.source: MicrosoftWindowsServer
trans-unit.target: MicrosoftWindowsServer

trans-unit.source: WindowsServer
trans-unit.target: WindowsServer

trans-unit.source: 2012-Datacenter
trans-unit.target: 2012-Datacenter

trans-unit.source: MicrosoftWindowsServer
trans-unit.target: MicrosoftWindowsServer

trans-unit.source: WindowsServer
trans-unit.target: WindowsServer

trans-unit.source: 2012-R2-Datacenter
trans-unit.target: 2012-R2-Datacenter

trans-unit.source: MicrosoftDynamicsNAV
trans-unit.target: MicrosoftDynamicsNAV

trans-unit.source: DynamicsNAV
trans-unit.target: DynamicsNAV

trans-unit.source: MicrosoftSharePoint
trans-unit.target: MicrosoftSharePoint

trans-unit.source: MicrosoftSharePointServer
trans-unit.target: MicrosoftSharePointServer

trans-unit.source: MicrosoftSQLServer
trans-unit.target: MicrosoftSQLServer

trans-unit.source: Enterprise-Optimized-for-DW
trans-unit.target: Enterprise-Optimized-for-DW

trans-unit.source: MicrosoftSQLServer
trans-unit.target: MicrosoftSQLServer

trans-unit.source: Enterprise-Optimized-for-OLTP
trans-unit.target: Enterprise-Optimized-for-OLTP

trans-unit.source: MicrosoftWindowsServerEssentials
trans-unit.target: MicrosoftWindowsServerEssentials

trans-unit.source: WindowsServerEssentials
trans-unit.target: WindowsServerEssentials

trans-unit.source: WindowsServerEssentials
trans-unit.target: WindowsServerEssentials

trans-unit.source: MicrosoftWindowsServerHPCPack
trans-unit.target: MicrosoftWindowsServerHPCPack

trans-unit.source: WindowsServerHPCPack
trans-unit.target: WindowsServerHPCPack

trans-unit.source: If the virtual machine image you need is not listed, use the instructions [here](resource-groups-vm-searching.md#powershell) to determine the publisher, offer, and SKU names.
trans-unit.target: If the virtual machine image you need is not listed, use the instructions [here](resource-groups-vm-searching.md#powershell) to determine the publisher, offer, and SKU names.

trans-unit.source: Copy these commands to your command set and fill in the publisher, offer, and SKU names.
trans-unit.target: Copy these commands to your command set and fill in the publisher, offer, and SKU names.

trans-unit.source: Finally, copy these commands to your command set and fill in the name identifier for the operating system disk for the VM.
trans-unit.target: Finally, copy these commands to your command set and fill in the name identifier for the operating system disk for the VM.

trans-unit.source: Step 5: Run your command set
trans-unit.target: Step 5: Run your command set

trans-unit.source: Review the Azure PowerShell command set you built in your text editor or the PowerShell ISE consisting of multiple blocks of commands from Step 4.
trans-unit.target: Review the Azure PowerShell command set you built in your text editor or the PowerShell ISE consisting of multiple blocks of commands from Step 4.

trans-unit.source: Ensure that you have specified all the needed variables and that they have the correct values.
trans-unit.target: Ensure that you have specified all the needed variables and that they have the correct values.

trans-unit.source: Also make sure that you have removed all the < and > characters.
trans-unit.target: Also make sure that you have removed all the < and > characters.

trans-unit.source: If you have your commands in a text editor, copy the command set to the clipboard and then right-click your open Azure PowerShell prompt.
trans-unit.target: If you have your commands in a text editor, copy the command set to the clipboard and then right-click your open Azure PowerShell prompt.

trans-unit.source: This will issue the command set as a series of PowerShell commands and create your Azure virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: This will issue the command set as a series of PowerShell commands and create your Azure virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Alternately, run the command set from the Azure PowerShell ISE.
trans-unit.target: Alternately, run the command set from the Azure PowerShell ISE.

trans-unit.source: If you will be creating this virtual machine again or a similar one, you can save this command set as a PowerShell script file (*.ps1).
trans-unit.target: If you will be creating this virtual machine again or a similar one, you can save this command set as a PowerShell script file (*.ps1).

trans-unit.source: Example
trans-unit.target: Example

trans-unit.source: I need a PowerShell command set to create an additional virtual machine for a web-based line-of-business workload that:
trans-unit.target: I need a PowerShell command set to create an additional virtual machine for a web-based line-of-business workload that:

trans-unit.source: Is placed in the existing LOBServers resource group
trans-unit.target: Is placed in the existing LOBServers resource group

trans-unit.source: Uses the Windows Server 2012 R2 Datacenter image
trans-unit.target: Uses the Windows Server 2012 R2 Datacenter image

trans-unit.source: Has the name LOB07 and is in the existing WEB_AS availability set
trans-unit.target: Has the name LOB07 and is in the existing WEB_AS availability set

trans-unit.source: Has a NIC with a public IP address in the FrontEnd subnet (subnet index 0) of the existing AZDatacenter virtual network
trans-unit.target: Has a NIC with a public IP address in the FrontEnd subnet (subnet index 0) of the existing AZDatacenter virtual network

trans-unit.source: Has an additional data disk of 200 GB
trans-unit.target: Has an additional data disk of 200 GB

trans-unit.source: Here is the corresponding Azure PowerShell command set to create this virtual machine, based on the process described in Step 4.
trans-unit.target: Here is the corresponding Azure PowerShell command set to create this virtual machine, based on the process described in Step 4.
